title: Dear Search Engine: What’s your opinion about...? - Sentiment Analysis for Semantic Enrichment of Web Search Results

author: Gianluca Demartini, L3S Research Center, Leibniz University of Hannover

segmentation: Good morning.

I am John Luke Demartini from the Alpheus Research Center in Germany, and I present the work entitled, Dear Sir, changing What's your opinion about which is a work about sentiment analysis of web search results.
So as we all know, the content on the web keeps growing all the time.
And today at least search engines are the main way users on the web can access content.
So for this reason, what the users can see about the web is what the search engine show showed them.
At the same time, we know that controversial topics are being discussed on the web.
People are talking on blogs.
They can say anything they want about any topic and also news.
Opinions of important personnel reported and so on.
So putting these two things together.
We can conclude that search engine can bias the way we see the content on the web, and they could do this, but just by showing us some part of the content.
So therefore it is important to provide a good overview in the few top results of search engine query.
Both from the topical dimension topical perspective, so we may want to diversify the search results in order to provide a good overview.

A topical overview about the query, but also we might want to do this from a sentiment perspective, so the goal would be to show the user in the top three 5 results all the different opinions about the controversial topic the user is looking for.
So in this problem.
We work what we want to do towards this direction.
We want to propose some approaches for computing the sentiment expressed in web pages.
And we do a preliminary experimental analysis where we compare free commercial search engines, how they, what they return to the users.
Also, comparing what is the opinion in the few top results compared to the one ranked lower?
So will present how it is possible to announce such results using sentiment.
Some related areas where we can find techniques where we can apply techniques.
Then I present specific methods for extract the sentiment from web pages and the results of the experimental study, and at the end I will show some direct.
And for future work.
So just to make clear the the idea, we have a user of a search engine who types out in Asia, which is a controversial topic.
So there are opinions in favor of this an against this and we get back a ranked list of documents.
So the idea is to announce these results with some annotation about the sentiment expressed in these results.
So this is just one way, but there may be others to show the user that the opinion expressed, so we might have a number or a color saying this page is against or is in favor of the topic.

So this allows the user to have an idea of what's the opinion on the web about this topic, and then you feel look at this at the document for example, the first one where the the annotation tells us that it is a negative opinion about the topic.
We find sentences like killing another person is wrong or there is no quality of life.
If the patient is dead, which strongly show how this website is against Attanasio.
So the next question, if you want to do this is what is then the the either ranking.
So the goal is to provide a good overview from the sentiment perspective to the user.
But what is a good overview?
So there may be different answers we may want to show in the top few results what we call a balanced overview.
So a mix of strongly positive and strongly negative documents about the topic.
Another option is to provide a neutral overview so we only show documents which are very objective and neutral about the topics they show.
Not extremely, but somehow they provide an overview already.
Another option is to provide the realistic overview, so if the search engine knows what is the public opinion about the topic.
For example, we know that 80% of the population is against Nazism, then the search engine results may reflect these public opinion and they may contain 80% of negative documents about the topic.
The fourth option is can be applied when the search engine knows who the user is and what the user likes and can personalize the results.
Showing only documents that things alike.
OK, in order to do this there are different fields where we can look at one is.
The field that tries to study the biasing search engines and this has been done mainly from the topical POV.
So is 1 search engine showing only a subtopic as compared to other search engines.
This was done mainly on the content of the web page and on the URL level, so we want to do a similar similar work, but on the sentiment perspective.
Very hot topic is that one of search result diversification where we want to solve the tradeoff between relevance and diversification of results where diversification is usually measured with.
Distance measure based on the content of the web pages so we could do a similar thing measuring the distance from the sentiment at the sentiment level.
Then, in order to compute such sentiment, we may look at opinion mining, which was mainly applied on blog content, which is a perfect setting where to study opinions.
Because people talk about their opinions about movies or any other topic.
And then there is of course the field of phonetic search results as we show today.
Search engine shows US Maps or numbers or riviews whatever, so this would be one more enriching of the search result.
So how we can then do the extraction of sentiment from web pages.
In this work we tried two different things.
One is using a lexicon of sentimental words, which is called senti word net.
And the other is used test text classification where we trained using movie reviews manually labeled in positive and negatives linear supporting vector machine classifier.
So having these two tool given a web page, we first.
Get out all the sentences from the web page.

So that we can either look at sentences containing the user query so we are sure that that sentence is about the user query, or that all the sentences in the document, and then we either classify the sentence using our text classifier and we get back a binary decision.
Or we can compute the average sentiment of the sentence and using the lexicon.
And we did this by.
Considering all the objectives, so we need to do a part of speech tagging of the sentence.
We take out the objectives and then we look up in the lexicon, which is the score of each objective.
So in this way we can compute averages an at the end for one document.
We have one score which may be positive or negative with some degree.
OK, combining all these options together we get different methods and the possible combinations are.
As I said, we can.
We consider only sentences containing the query term or all the sentences in the page and we can assign to the page either at the binary decision.
It's positive it's negative or eventually also it's objective or the real numbers.
What the.
Then classifier tell us as the distance from the hyperplane or the combination of the scores in the lexicon.
OK, given all these methods, we're.
Some experiments and we compare the the opinion expressed in the top 50 results.
From three different search engines, about 14 manually selected queries that we consider the controversial.
So which kind of observation we can do?
So in this setting.
The first thing we could do is compare different methods.
And one one conclusion we can draw is that looking only at the sentences containing the query terms.
Return is more positive.
Opinion then, looking at the entire text of the webpage.
Another more interesting observation is which is the sentiment for different search engines.
OK, there is no big news about this.
We can see that the average sentiment is anyway very close to 0, so there are no strong opinions showed by search engines and there is no big difference between search engines.
While Yahoo is much closer to do an objective overview of the topics.

It's it's you cannot say one is more objective than another.
OK, another observation we can do is looking at the ranking of results and here we can actually conclude that the 1st results it's an average more positive than others.
For all the search engines we observed.

Some OK abortion.

OK, yeah.

I mean this is not easy problem by itself, so here you assume this it's true.
So we did.

So that's a good point.
But so somehow.
We assume that the tool provides us a reasonable classification or the sentiment, and then we do some analysis.
I agree that the first thing we should do.
Is to assess the quality of our annotations.
Probably mainly by asking users whether the the the sentiment expressed in the page by reading the pages.
The same as the one computed by the machine.
OK, so about the future work.
Having available such annotations.
Cannot can help us explain the user what is the opinion expressed in the search engine results?
So as we said, what we want, the first thing we want to do next is.
Two to judge the quality of our sentiment classification methods and also to ask users whether it is useful to have such.
Analysis of the sentiment of pages and also to create these overview of opinions on the web about the topic.
So more in detail about the sentiment diversification.
We we can detect if you are able to diversify the sentiment.
If the top few results are a good sample of all the other results.
From the sentiment POV and in this way we will be able to evaluate how good our currents are changing in a diversified the sentiment.
And then we have one more interesting question, which is how topic and sentiment diversity interact.
So today there are papers dealing with the tradeoff between relevance and topical diversity.
Then the question would be if we also had the sentiment diversity, how can we deal with these three different dimensions?
And then there are very interesting application.
If we think that we can think of when we are able to do such sentiment analysis.
So as we said, we may want to do any ranking of the results in order to produce a good overview in the top few results, which is an NP hard problem.
But there are good approximation.
Another interesting question is how fair is Wikipedia so?
Wikipedia is a free encyclopedia where everyone can edit the pages.
But there's an encyclopedia.
It should be objective also about controversial topics.
So the question is how objective it is.
And then so on one side we can ask users how this is good, but we can also do some experiments on on static collection and not on the living web.
And ask question like how?
Our ranking features like being 25 or page rank influence the sentiment in the top few.
So we might expect that page rank increases or favors positive pages because positive pages may have modern links, so these are all open questions that we want to investigate.
And then also, what is the difference between the search results and the public opinion?
So is public opinion reflected in search results?
As we said, if people in the blogs are talking badly against Nazis, is this reflected in the search engine results?
Thanks.

Any other questions?
So I have a question.
